body: Minor: 4-spaces here too.

diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,5 @@
+{
+     // An invalid form feed character (\x0c) has been entered before this comment.
+    // Be careful not to delete it.
+  "a": true
body: Minor: let's standardize on 4-spaces. I know some of the test files use 2, sorry about that. =)

A few questions about this:
1. Why do you need to see whether a `\n` is the next character? Is `\r` by itself not enough to ignore?
2. Why is this within the `if (ch === '\\')` block? Isn't this looking at carriage returns only after an escaped backslash? Why not put this further down, next to the regular `ch === '\n'` check?

Ah, ignore the second question; I understand. I forgot that our multi-line strings require a backslash escape, so this needs to come after that. =)

Still curious about the first q.

And btw, if `\r` by itself should be accepted too, then you might not need this block of code at all (nor `peek` of course). See the `escapee` dictionary up top (if you haven't already) where `\n` is handled.

body:
The lack of `$` in these bash snippets was actually intentional: it lets you copy-paste directly.

(There have been some fun blog posts written on this topic, and I just spent an unreasonable amount of time trying to find one, but couldn't. Hard to search for them...)

So would you mind reverting the additions of `$` in these snippets? Thanks!

body: Man, this is my fault since I missed your PR, but heck, may as well make this 2015 now. =D
Instead of referencing `args[2]` in multiple spots, let's add a variable to save it, e.g. `cmd` after `args`.
Also, is this boolean logic right? I thought `&&` takes precedence over `||`, so you might need to wrap the `-c || --validate` check in parentheses.
Code style: this file uses 4-space indentation.

What does the output look like for an invalid file? I assume `JSON5.parse` will throw an error, so you'll just get the stack trace. But that doesn't seem any different from what you reported in https://github.com/aseemk/json5/issues/72#issuecomment-59616865?

The fix, I _think_, would be to wrap the whole `FS.readFileSync` + `JSON5.parse` in a try/catch, and in the catch, log "<file> is invalid" along w/ the error `stack` trace. (But important: re-throw the error if compiling.)
Also minor code style: `if (` instead of `if(`.

body: Let's use `peek()` here instead of `ch2`. No need to introduce a one-time variable.
Also, `\r` by itself is a valid new line.

The rule here is simply taken from the ES5 LineTerminatorSequence production - https://es5.github.io/#x7.3 - we do indeed recognise \r as a valid newline as the test case verified, but we need to ensure not to recognise \r\n as two newlines.
I'd like to use a better name than `_number` here. Let's come up with a names that describe the difference between `number()` and `_number()`.
How about `numberLiteral` instead of `_number`?
This is why Travis CI is failing for Node 0.10 and 0.12. String.prototype.startsWith wasn't added until ES2015.

You can replace line 23 with:

```
  if (fn.substr(0, 1) == '.') {
```

to support older versions of JS. String.substr is close to 20 years old now :)

I made the change in my tree FWIW:
https://github.com/ianloic/json5/commit/65fc0bbe2118a5da192ad7b34238d07227677b39
@ianloic Thanks for the fix. Making changes to your tree is perfect since I can merge those in and you still get credit for the commits.
@jordanbtucker I don't need credit - especially for these little things. I've just been moving around the code y'all have already written.
More usual term here is "Precedence"

Why not support all operators which could legitimately operate on constants - therefore including !, ^, &, &&, |, and ||. I think there's no reason to exclude boolean constants from this work - therefore supporting true/false in addition to the numbers which have been already supported.
Support for arbitrary grouping using () would also round out this feature and make it more useful.
I know that `~-1 == 0 == false` but I don't see this used very often, so let's simplify this to `ws.indexOf(ch) >= 0` for readability.
Again, let's use `operator.indexOf(ch) >= 0`.
Ok...
